Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Michael J. Lopez of University of California, Los Angeles to conduct a research project, entitled "Novel catalytic reactions generating chemical bonds using abundant and cheap starting materials," during the summer of 2012 at University of Osaka in Osaka. The host scientist is Professor Hayato Tsurugi.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to develop dehydrogenative borylation catalysts using early-transition metals supported by redox-active ligands.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research at the University of Osaka under Professor Hayato Tsurugi involved running oxygen and moisture sensitive reactions using both the Schlenk line and glove box. These methods of eliminating contact with oxygen and water were necessary since the synthesized metal complexes were particularly unstable in air. The synthesized metal complexes belong to a subdivision of organometallic compounds called early-transition metal complexes supported by redox-active ligands. The focus of the project involved synthesizing and characterizing both niobium and tantalum complexes supported by diamidoferrocene ligands. The iron containing ferrocene moiety can electronically respond to the electronic fluctuations to the coordinated metal center via either receiving or donating an electron.

 

Reactions were examined using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. Proton NMR spectroscopy, a subtype of NMR spectroscopy, is universally implemented to characterize organometallic complexes containing diamagnetic metals. This is because paramagnetic metals interact with protons via mechanisms that interfere with data acquisition. EPR spectroscopy, specifically used for paramagnetic metals, was also used to characterize the products of the reactions. Both methods were used because the product produced from the reactions could be either diamagnetic or paramagnetic.

 

Initial reactions between group 5 metal precursors, trimethyl dichlorotantalum/ niobium, and diamidoferrocene gave complex and nonretractable mixtures. Throughout the course of the summer several different reaction conditions, such as changing the time or temperature of the reaction, were implemented along with using various diamidoferrocene ligands. This included reacting the group 5 metal precursors with both the neutral diamideferrocene and the anionic diamidoferrocene.

 

Continuation with this project is currently underway in the form of a collaboration between Professor Hayato Tsurugi and Professor Paula Diaconescu at University of California, Los Angeles. The NSF EAPSI program has given the researcher, who is an underrepresented minority, the unique opportunity to travel and complete research in Japan. Along with learning about various inorganic techniques, the research also was given the opportunity to learn about Japanese culture and society.  

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2012
Modified by: Michael J Lopez
